title: Tentative
description: Tentative is a podcast about digital product design. Hosted by thoughtbot Chief Design Officer Kyle Fiedler & Reda Lemeden.

items.title: 40: CoolGraphics.com
items.content_text: Kyle & Reda discuss search engines, documentation searches, reminisce about Photoshop Slices in Dreamweaver, and question Reda's Google-Fu.
items.content_html:
Kyle & Reda discuss search engines, documentation searches, reminisce about Photoshop Slices in Dreamweaver, and question Reda's Google-Fu.

  • DuckDuckGo
  • Dash Documentation
  • Dreamweaver
  • Keep Ruby Weird Call For Proposals
  • PSD2HTML
items.summary: Kyle & Reda discuss search engines, documentation searches, reminisce about Photoshop Slices in Dreamweaver, and question Reda's Google-Fu.

items.title: 39: Too Much Fiddling
items.content_text: Kyle & Dawn discuss end-of-project planning / organization, jobs vs user stories, and the merits of Austin TX.
items.content_html:
Kyle & Dawn discuss end-of-project planning / organization, jobs vs user stories, and the merits of Austin TX.

  • thoughtbot Home Page
  • Parent/Child Management for Trello
  • Converting to Jobs Stories
items.summary: Kyle & Dawn discuss end-of-project planning / organization, jobs vs user stories, and the merits of Austin TX.

items.title: 38: Grid Locked
items.content_text: Brenda joins Reda to discuss CSS Grid Layout, the reasons they don't use grid frameworks as much anymore, iPad design, and the pros/cons of client vs product work.
items.content_html:
Brenda joins Reda to discuss CSS Grid Layout, the reasons they don't use grid frameworks as much anymore, iPad design, and the pros/cons of client vs product work.

  • CSS Layout Club
  • CSS Working Group
  • "Learn CSS Grid"- Jen Simmons
  • Neat
items.summary: Brenda joins Reda to discuss CSS Grid Layout, the reasons they don't use grid frameworks as much anymore, iPad design, and the pros/cons of client vs product work.

items.title: 37: That Sounds Very Obvious Coming Out of My Mouth
items.content_text: Dawn and Kyle talk about Dawn’s recent experience running usability tests, and what learned from running them. Kyle discusses how he's using Jobs-to-be-done theory to build a marketing landing page. Finally, how they approach which resolution screen to design for first.
items.content_html: Dawn and Kyle talk about Dawn’s recent experience running usability tests, and what learned from running them. Kyle discusses how he's using Jobs-to-be-done theory to build a marketing landing page. Finally, how they approach which resolution screen to design for first.
items.summary: Dawn and Kyle talk about Dawn’s recent experience running usability tests, and what learned from running them. Kyle discusses how he's using Jobs-to-be-done theory to build a marketing landing page. Finally, how they approach which resolution screen to design for first.

items.title: 36: Floating in Space
items.content_text: Reda and Jack talk about design from the perspective of a developer, why CSS sucks for layout, retro game making, and App Store things.
items.content_html:
Reda and Jack talk about design from the perspective of a developer, why CSS sucks for layout, retro game making, and App Store things.

  • Jack’s Twitter
  • Safari default CSS
  • CSS Grid module
  • CSS Flexbox
  • Build Phase
  • Scribattle
  • FlippyBit
  • App Store purge
items.summary: Reda and Jack talk about design from the perspective of a developer, why CSS sucks for layout, retro game making, and App Store things.

items.title: 35: Design Debt
items.content_text: We talk about the dichotomy of perfection in design, versus shipping something that is 'good enough'. Reda discusses how he is keeping track of the places in the app that he wants to improve while trying to hit deadlines.  Also, recent experience jumping on print design and branding projects, and the different tools used when tackling them.
items.content_html: We talk about the dichotomy of perfection in design, versus shipping something that is 'good enough'. Reda discusses how he is keeping track of the places in the app that he wants to improve while trying to hit deadlines. Also, recent experience jumping on print design and branding projects, and the different tools used when tackling them.
items.summary: We talk about the dichotomy of perfection in design, versus shipping something that is 'good enough'. Reda discusses how he is keeping track of the places in the app that he wants to improve while trying to hit deadlines.  Also, recent experience jumping on print design and branding projects, and the different tools used when tackling them.

items.title: 34: Big Human Aspect
items.content_text: We discuss whether it is better to have a bunch of work waiting for you or none when getting back from a vacation, what it’s like being the only designer on a project, documenting design, and trends / style specifically for iOS (and how it relates to the web).
items.content_html:
We discuss whether it is better to have a bunch of work waiting for you or none when getting back from a vacation, what it’s like being the only designer on a project, documenting design, and trends / style specifically for iOS (and how it relates to the web).

  • Ottoneu Fantasy Baseball
  • Bear Notes App
items.summary: We discuss whether it is better to have a bunch of work waiting for you or none when getting back from a vacation, what it’s like being the only designer on a project, documenting design, and trends / style specifically for iOS (and how it relates to the web).

items.title: 33: Design Speak
items.content_text: Kyle is joined by Jaclyn Perrone to talk about designing with seed data, and how to make a new interface not look empty. They discuss using jobs-to-be-done to influence a product through interviews and job statements, as well as how they approach designing with users in mind, and the value of real users' reactions when testing interfaces.
items.content_html:
Kyle is joined by Jaclyn Perrone to talk about designing with seed data, and how to make a new interface not look empty. They discuss using jobs-to-be-done to influence a product through interviews and job statements, as well as how they approach designing with users in mind, and the value of real users' reactions when testing interfaces.

  • Jobs-to-be-done
  • Design sprints
  • Alan Klement
  • Design sprint episode with Reda
  • Remote design sprint episode with Dawn
  • Jaclyn Perrone
items.summary: Kyle is joined by Jaclyn Perrone to talk about designing with seed data, and how to make a new interface not look empty. They discuss using jobs-to-be-done to influence a product through interviews and job statements, as well as how they approach designing with users in mind, and the value of real users' reactions when testing interfaces.

items.title: 32: Sprinting Remotely
items.content_text:
Kyle is joined by Dawn Delatte to discuss the different tools and methodology employed in tackling a remote design sprint. They cover some of the success and failures of a recent sprint and how they split up work afterwards.

Dawn talks about diving into JavaScript which leads to a discussion on how they learn new technology and design techniques. Kyle is back on a rails app and is enjoying planning out the product.
items.content_html:
Kyle is joined by Dawn Delatte to discuss the different tools and methodology employed in tackling a remote design sprint. They cover some of the success and failures of a recent sprint and how they split up work afterwards.

Dawn talks about diving into JavaScript which leads to a discussion on how they learn new technology and design techniques. Kyle is back on a rails app and is enjoying planning out the product.

  • Trello Board For Design Sprints
  • Trello App
  • Realtimeboard - Whiteboard App
  • Fullstory
  • JavaScript For Web Designers
  • Jobs Stories
  • Sketch
  • Invision
  • Lulu Miller Tedx Talk
  • Kyle Recording Under a Coat
  • Dawn on Twitter
  • Dawn's Website
items.summary:
Kyle is joined by Dawn Delatte to discuss the different tools and methodology employed in tackling a remote design sprint. They cover some of the success and failures of a recent sprint and how they split up work afterwards.

Dawn talks about diving into JavaScript which leads to a discussion on how they learn new technology and design techniques. Kyle is back on a rails app and is enjoying planning out the product.

items.title: 31: A Whiff of a Story
items.content_text: They're back! Reda and Kyle team up for a new season of Tentative. In this episode we discuss the thought process, tools, and execution plan for goals and resolutions in the new year. Plus, books for Reda to read over the coming year, and the importance of reading not only as a designer but also as a person.
items.content_html:
They're back! Reda and Kyle team up for a new season of Tentative. In this episode we discuss the thought process, tools, and execution plan for goals and resolutions in the new year. Plus, books for Reda to read over the coming year, and the importance of reading not only as a designer but also as a person.

  • Gina Bolton’s V2MOM
  • Getting Things Done
  • Moonwalking with Einstein
  • Kindle
  • Competing Against Luck- Clayton Christiansen
  • Kale and Coffee Compete- Alan Klement
  • Making Sense of Color Management- Craig Hockenberry
  • Creativity Inc.
  • Thinking Fast and Slow
items.summary: They're back! Reda and Kyle team up for a new season of Tentative. In this episode we discuss the thought process, tools, and execution plan for goals and resolutions in the new year. Plus, books for Reda to read over the coming year, and the importance of reading not only as a designer but also as a person.

items.title: 30: 50 Shades of Blue
items.content_text: Using Instagram’s redesign as an example, we discuss the new wave of apps that are starting a trend of black and white UI. This leads to a debate on having concrete style trends, and why it doesn’t always make sense to follow them (but why it might make sense for Instagram).
items.content_html:
Using Instagram’s redesign as an example, we discuss the new wave of apps that are starting a trend of black and white UI. This leads to a debate on having concrete style trends, and why it doesn’t always make sense to follow them (but why it might make sense for Instagram).

  • Episode about burnout
  • Reda’s tweet
  • Instagram redesign
  • Reda’s Build Phase Episode
  • Laila & Brenda Show
items.summary: Using Instagram’s redesign as an example, we discuss the new wave of apps that are starting a trend of black and white UI. This leads to a debate on having concrete style trends, and why it doesn’t always make sense to follow them (but why it might make sense for Instagram).

items.title: 29: A Midsummer Night's Podcast
items.content_text: Reda and Kyle talk about how Kyle is tackling a branding project for a fantasy sports app. They then dig into how both are planning for upcoming design sprints, and the methodology behind their different approaches.
items.content_html:
Reda and Kyle talk about how Kyle is tackling a branding project for a fantasy sports app. They then dig into how both are planning for upcoming design sprints, and the methodology behind their different approaches.

  • Stattleship Logo Dribbble

  • Reda’s WWDC post
  • HiRes with Kyle
items.summary: Reda and Kyle talk about how Kyle is tackling a branding project for a fantasy sports app. They then dig into how both are planning for upcoming design sprints, and the methodology behind their different approaches.

items.title: 28: A Big Blob of Happiness
items.content_text: This episode Reda and Kyle talk about WWDC. They review new features for both iOS and the Apple Watch before discussing Apple's public attitude towards design, and speculate about the process Apple follows building software.
items.content_html:
This episode Reda and Kyle talk about WWDC. They review new features for both iOS and the Apple Watch before discussing Apple's public attitude towards design, and speculate about the process Apple follows building software.

items.title: 27: Rollercoaster of Feelings
items.content_text: This episode Reda and Kyle start off by talking about podcasting competition and Reda's childhood psychology.  Then they talk about how both are tackling SVG and walk away with different feelings about it. Reda wraps up by bashing HAML while Kyle tries to defend its pros.
items.content_html:
This episode Reda and Kyle start off by talking about podcasting competition and Reda's childhood psychology. Then they talk about how both are tackling SVG and walk away with different feelings about it. Reda wraps up by bashing HAML while Kyle tries to defend its pros.

items.title: 26: Vector of a Tack
items.content_text: This week Reda and Kyle talk about content and typography, how both apply to the web, and why they try to use real content as much as possible. Also, the problems that they run into when designing forms and the trade offs between usability and style.
items.content_html:
This week Reda and Kyle talk about content and typography, how both apply to the web, and why they try to use real content as much as possible. Also, the problems that they run into when designing forms and the trade offs between usability and style.

  • Brutalist websites
  • WWDC

items.title: 25: Everything's a Nail
items.content_text: Reda and Kyle talk about the new thoughtbot.com. Kyle explains some of the reasons why they redesigned instead of iterating over the existing design. They talk about parts of their process and how tools like code and graphical editors fit in. They discuss the balance between shipping and getting pixel perfection. They wrap up talking about how they balance multiple projects and multiple tasks.
items.content_html:
Reda and Kyle talk about the new thoughtbot.com. Kyle explains some of the reasons why they redesigned instead of iterating over the existing design. They talk about parts of their process and how tools like code and graphical editors fit in. They discuss the balance between shipping and getting pixel perfection. They wrap up talking about how they balance multiple projects and multiple tasks.

They wrap up talking about how they balance multiple projects and multiple tasks.

items.title: 24: Hunky Dory All the Time
items.content_text: On this episode Reda and Kyle rehash their conversation about Should designers code. They talk about teams and how design should fit in. They discuss design and design thinking at a high level in the company and design leadership in our community.
items.content_html:
On this episode Reda and Kyle rehash their conversation about Should designers code. They talk about teams and how design should fit in. They discuss design and design thinking at a high level in the company and design leadership in our community.

  • Cap Watkins Blog

items.title: 23: Darkish-Gray Patterns
items.content_text: Cheerful Reda and Kyle talk about ethics in their work. Discussion hovers around dark patterns in design. They talk about dark patterns with cable companies, airlines, and domain registrars. And how dark patterns can effect the long term sustainability of the business. Kyle talks about the technology he's been using on parental leave and his purchase of an Apple Watch.
items.content_html:
Cheerful Reda and Kyle talk about ethics in their work. Discussion hovers around dark patterns in design. They talk about dark patterns with cable companies, airlines, and domain registrars. And how dark patterns can effect the long term sustainability of the business. Kyle talks about the technology he's been using on parental leave and his purchase of an Apple Watch.

  • The Dark Side
  • Apple Watch
  • Darkpatterns.org

They talk about dark patterns with cable companies, airlines, and domain registrars. And how dark patterns can effect the long term sustainability of the business. Kyle talks about the technology he's been using on parental leave and his purchase of an Apple Watch.

items.title: 22: Best of Both Words
items.content_text: Reda and Kyle talk about writing as a designer. What their process is for writing, what the process is like writing for thoughtbot, and how they differentiate posts on thoughtbot’s blog and their personal blog. Plus Reda goes on a rant against Medium.
items.content_html:
Reda and Kyle talk about writing as a designer. What their process is for writing, what the process is like writing for thoughtbot, and how they differentiate posts on thoughtbot’s blog and their personal blog. Plus Reda goes on a rant against Medium.

items.title: 21: Snapchat For Design Feedback
items.content_text: This week Reda and Kyle talk about tools for collaborative design feedback. They talk about how they’ve used tools at thoughtbot and what are the pros and cons of each of the tools. They also talk about how they use these tools to get feedback from other designers in different thoughtbot offices for more varied design feedback.
items.content_html:
This week Reda and Kyle talk about tools for collaborative design feedback. They talk about how they’ve used tools at thoughtbot and what are the pros and cons of each of the tools. They also talk about how they use these tools to get feedback from other designers in different thoughtbot offices for more varied design feedback.

They also talk about how they use these tools to get feedback from other designers in different thoughtbot offices for more varied design feedback.

items.title: 20: Minimal Viable Design
items.content_text: In this episode Red-A and Kyle talk about product design and development at thoughtbot. They go over how they use tools like Trello and Slack to communicate with their teams and their clients and how design fits into that process. They talk about how they validate design decisions and argue about the proper pronunciation of GIF.

items.title: 19: Death to GUIs
items.content_text: During this episode, Reda and Kyle talk about conversational user interfaces. They talk about popular implementations of conversational UIs, how they use these tools and what effect it has on the future of graphical user interface.
items.content_html: During this episode, Reda and Kyle talk about conversational user interfaces. They talk about popular implementations of conversational UIs, how they use these tools and what effect it has on the future of graphical user interface.

items.title: 18: It's Not Satisfying Unless You Blow Into the Cartridge
items.content_text: In this episode Reda and Kyle talk about the homogenization in web design. How styles have evolved in the past and how they see style trends in graphic design evolving in the future. They discuss the issues and problems facing archiving application design. What they use Dribbble for and what kind of a tool it is now.
items.content_html:
In this episode Reda and Kyle talk about the homogenization in web design. How styles have evolved in the pas and how they see style trends in graphic design evolving in the future. They discuss the issues and problems facing archiving application design. What they use Dribbble for and what kind of a tool it is now.

items.title: 17: Let's Talk About CSS Baby (Lets Talk About You and Me)
items.content_text: During this episode, Reda and Kyle talk about their qualms with CSS. They talk about CSS naming conventions, how they tackle layout and the wonderful world of flexbox. Kyle tries to educate Reda on some early 90’s pop music and fails.
items.content_html:

items.title: 16: Master of IE
items.content_text: In this episode Reda and Kyle talk about browser testing. They discuss how they approach testing each browser and operating system and devices. They talk about the differences in type rendering, browser user interface, and layout. Reda talks about how he approaches a simple fluid layout, Kyle talks about his most recent project and some layout challenges and they talk about using CSS for layout.
items.content_html:

items.title: 15: X is bad for Y
items.content_text: In this episode Reda and Kyle discuss iteration and design process. They talk about the differences between how a junior designer takes on a project and how a senior designer takes on a project. Kyle talks about how jobs to be done fits into his design process. They also go on a few tangents of tracking personal data and posting articles on medium.

items.title: 13: Designing For Human Emotion
items.content_text: This week Reda and Kyle talk about empathy in design and keeping in mind a users state of mind while designing. They give examples when when humor and playfulness are good to add into user experience and some cases when it isn't.
items.content_html:

items.title: 12: How Many Questions Do You Ask?
items.content_text: This episode Reda and Kyle talk about the thoughtbot hiring process for designers. They talk about what they look for in designers, what they look for in a portfolio, and details about each step in the hiring process.
items.content_html:

items.title: 11: Your Favicon is Ugly
items.content_text: Reda and Kyle follow up on SVGs, talk about differences between Chrome and new Safari's pinned tabs. They discuss some of the ways of allowing users control over design and themes of the app they are designing. Lastly they talk about how they design with real content or as close to as real as possible. BONUS: Kyle sings a line of Aerosmith.

They discuss some of the ways of allowing users control over design and themes of the app they are designing. items.title: 10: Doing Things the Hard Way (Brenda Storer)
items.content_text:
In this episode, Brenda Storer stands in for the vacationing Reda. Brenda and Kyle talk about Brenda's recent talk on SVG's. The in's and out's of her process of learning about them and talking about them. They also talk about giving talks.

This episode of Tentative is sponsored by Code School. Entertaining online learning for existing and aspiring developers. Leave a review on our iTunes page to be entered to win a free month of Code School.

In this episode, Brenda Storer stands in for the vacationing Reda. Brenda and Kyle talk about Brenda's recent talk on SVG's. The in's and out's of her process of learning about them and talking about them. They also talk about giving talks.

This episode of The Bike Shed is sponsored by:

  • Code School: Entertaining online learning for existing and aspiring developers. Leave a review on our iTunes page to be entered to win a free month of Code School.

Links and Show Notes

  • Slides from the talk

  • Sara Soueidan's 2014 CSSConf talk
  • Jacob Jenkov's SVG Book online
  • Chris Coyier's technique for using symbols as icons in svgs
  • Jake Archibald's article on animating a stroke
  • Iconic Icon Responsive Icons
  • ManhattanJS website with animated clouds
  • Brenda on Twitter
items.summary:
In this episode, Brenda Storer stands in for the vacationing Reda. Brenda and Kyle talk about Brenda's recent talk on SVG's. The in's and out's of her process of learning about them and talking about them. They also talk about giving talks.

This episode of Tentative is sponsored by Code School. Entertaining online learning for existing and aspiring developers. Leave a review on our iTunes page to be entered to win a free month of Code School.

items.title: 9: Should Designers Code?
items.content_text:
In this episode, Kyle and Reda tackle the 'should designers code' debate. They talk about the differences between designing vs implementing, what to look for in a good designer and if developers should know how to design.

This episode of Tentative is sponsored by Code School. Entertaining online learning for existing and aspiring developers. Leave a review on our iTunes page to be entered to win a free month of Code School.

items.title: 7: Hamburgers Are an Abomination
items.content_text: In this episode, Kyle talks about his current project, Reda talks a lot about accessibility and how he designs for it, and Kyle trolls Reda into a rant about the Hamburger icon.
items.content_html:
In this episode, Kyle talks about his current project, Reda talks a lot about accessibility and how he designs for it, and Kyle trolls Reda into a rant about the Hamburger icon.

  • World Accessibility Day
  • Color Oracle is free Mac app to help you view your designs through the eyes of someone with color Blindness
  • Xscope has a bunch of utilities one of which can view colors from different types of color blindness.
  • Obvious always wins by Luke W
  • Not mentioned but we recommend watching Web Accessibility Wilderness Guide
